Award.AwardTitle: Synthetic and Biological Studies of Chondroitin Sulfate Oligosaccharides and Glycopeptides
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Xuefei Huang from Michigan State University to study the synthesis and functions of chondroitin sulfate (CS) and chondroitin sulfate proteoglycans (CSPG). Carbohydrates play important roles in many biological processes. However, due to the lack of uniformity of complex carbohydrate structures in nature, it has been very challenging to thoroughly understand their function. This project will focus on one specific class of carbohydrates referred to as chondroitin sulfate (CS) and chondroitin sulfate proteoglycans (CSPG), chondroitin sulfate that is bonded to protein. New synthetic approaches will be developed to produce these complex molecules, which will greatly expand the range of structures that can be accessed through chemical synthesis. With these materials, it will be possible to establish the impact of different structures on the interactions of CS and CSPG with, for example, amyloid beta peptide, the precursor to the aggregates and plaques that are present in the brains of people with Alzheimer's disease. In addition, the engagement of graduate, undergraduate and high school researchers in this project will provide them with opportunities to be trained in the important and challenging field of complex carbohydrate synthesis. The results generated will provide a highlight for the power of synthetic chemistry, and how chemical synthesis can be utilized to address important biological problems.

Chondroitin sulfate (CS) and chondroitin sulfate proteoglycans (CSPG) are involved in many important biological events including neural development, organ morphogenesis, inflammation, infection and beta amyloid plaque formation. The number and location of O-sulfates in CS and CSPG can significantly influence their biological properties. As naturally existing CS and CSPG contain heterogeneous sulfation patterns, it is highly challenging to decipher the detailed structure function relationship using CS and CSPG isolated from nature. Contradicting results have been reported in the literature. In order to overcome this problem and facilitate biological studies, synthetic methodologies will be developed to produce CS oligosaccharides and CSPG glycopeptides with well-defined sulfation patterns and structures. The utility of these compounds will be demonstrated in the study of CS/CSPG interactions with beta-amyloid peptide to investigate a potential mechanism for the formation of amyloid plaques, a pathological hallmark of Alzheimer's disease.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Chondroitin sulfate (CS) and chondroitin sulfate proteoglycans (CSPG) belong to the glycosaminoglycan (GAG) family, a class of poly-anionic glyco-conjugates widely expressed by animal cells. They are involved in many important biological events including neural development, organ morphogenesis, inflammation, infection and β amyloid plaque formation. The number and location of O-sulfates in CS and CSPG can significantly influence their biological properties. As naturally existing CS and CSPG contain heterogeneous sulfation patterns, it is highly challenging to decipher the detailed structure function relationship using CS and CSPG isolated from nature. Contradicting results have been reported in the literature. In order to overcome this problem and facilitate biological studies, in this project, we have developed synthetic methodologies to produce CS oligosaccharides and CSPG glycopeptides. 

To date, most of the reported CS synthesis produces relatively short oligosaccharides (fewer than 10 glycan units). However, natural CS exists as a polysaccharide with more than 20 units. In order to better study functions of CS, longer CS chains are needed. We have developed efficient synthetic strategies that have enabled us to successfully prepare a CS chain with 24 units. This is the longest CS chain that has been assembled to date.

It is known that the biological functions of CSPG can be dependent upon both the glycan chain and the core protein. However, no synthetic strategies to access CSPG were available. To overcome this obstacle, we have established an effective approach to synthesize CSPG glycopeptides. This is the first time such molecules are synthesized.  The availability of these compounds will greatly aid in the understanding of the roles CS/CSPG play in biological systems.

The proposed project has had a broad and significant impact on many areas of glyco-sciences. First, this project has advanced synthetic chemistry by establishing new methods to access CS oligosaccharides and CSPG glycopeptides. The knowledge gained from preparation of these challenging structures will facilitate the synthesis of other glycosaminoglycan molecules and proteoglycans. The successful completion of this project has demonstrated the power of synthetic chemistry and how synthesis can be utilized to help address important biological problems.

Another aspect of the broader impact lies in student training. Through the proposed research, students have received training in total synthesis and how to use tools of chemistry to answer biological questions, which will be invaluable for their future scientific career. Under-represented and under-privileged minority students have been incorporated into our research team through a wide range of programs geared towards these students.  This helps to broaden the future talent pool for science.

To enhance the broader impact of the project and serve the broader glyco-community, we have been actively involved in the Carbohydrate Chemistry division of the American Chemical Society, as well as editorial activities of the Journal of Carbohydrate Chemistry. We have organized the 14th Annual Midwest Carbohydrate and Glycobiology Symposium, a conference focused on glycoscience with around 100 participants from 16 research groups located throughout US.
